H0.text: Non-native plants are able to mutate rapidly when taken to a new habitat, which allows them to threaten native plants of that habitat.

H1.text: Non‑native plants cause native animals to relocate when introduced to a new habitat, thereby threatening native plants.

H2.text: Non‑native plants are able to be used for medicine, which is why they threaten native plants when taken to a new habitat.

H3.text: Non‑native plants compete with native plants for resources when taken to a new habitat, thereby threatening native plants.

A4.text: An introduced species that can spread faster than natives can outcompete native species for food, squeezing the natives out.

A5.text: Invasive species cause competition for native species, and because of this 400 of the 958 endangered species under the Endangered Species Act are at risk.
